d16afa0ae7c.description: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales. Part of WIRED Media Group.
d16afa0ae7c.name: Backchannel
d16afa0ae7c.shortDescription: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales.

paragraphs.name: db4b
paragraphs.text: Remember: if you’re having phone calls, the deal is still on. Phone calls are yesses, emails are nos.

Here’s a data point for you: As part of our push to woo Facebook, I had been getting Google Alerts on the company for months. One in particular had caught my attention. In October 2010, a mother in Florida had shaken her baby to death, as the baby would interrupt her FarmVille games with crying. A mother destroyed with her own hands what she’d been programmed over aeons to love, just to keep on responding to Facebook notifications triggered by some idiot game. Products that cause mothers to murder their infants in order to use them more, assuming they’re legal, simply cannot fail in the world. Facebook was legalized crack, and at Internet scale. Such a company could certainly figure out a way to sell shoes. Twitter was cute and all, but it didn’t have a casualty rate yet, no matter how much this Lady Gaga person was tweeting.
paragraphs.name: f058

paragraphs.text: It was time to come clean with the boys. I couldn’t morally justify the deception any longer.

But here’s a truth about tech life: anyone who claims the Valley is meritocratic is someone who has profited vastly from it via nonmeritocratic means like happenstance, membership in a privileged cohort, or some concealed act of absolute skulduggery. Since fortune had never been on my side, and I had no privileged cohort to fall back on, skulduggery it would have to be.
paragraphs.name: e565

paragraphs.text: Here’s a data point for you: As part of our push to woo Facebook, I had been getting Google Alerts on the company for months. One in particular had caught my attention. In October 2010, a mother in Florida had shaken her baby to death, as the baby would interrupt her FarmVille games with crying. A mother destroyed with her own hands what she’d been programmed over aeons to love, just to keep on responding to Facebook notifications triggered by some idiot game. Products that cause mothers to murder their infants in order to use them more, assuming they’re legal, simply cannot fail in the world. Facebook was legalized crack, and at Internet scale. Such a company could certainly figure out a way to sell shoes. Twitter was cute and all, but it didn’t have a casualty rate yet, no matter how much this Lady Gaga person was tweeting.
paragraphs.name: f058
e565
paragraphs.text: But here’s a truth about tech life: anyone who claims the Valley is meritocratic is someone who has profited vastly from it via nonmeritocratic means like happenstance, membership in a privileged cohort, or some concealed act of absolute skulduggery. Since fortune had never been on my side, and I had no privileged cohort to fall back on, skulduggery it would have to be.

Life is life. There’s often no good or bad, but simply the reality of things. It is what it is. It’s easy to judge from the outside perspective, to say that I’d have done this or that, but in the heat of the moment, we’re all human and have our own self-preservation needs first. There are of course heroes and selfless individuals, but even they make…

2fc0ccce30b1.title: From this post it appears that by taking the Facebook offer Antonio cost his co-founders and…

paragraphs.text: From this post it appears that by taking the Facebook offer Antonio cost his co-founders and investors five million dollars. Considering that he could have gone to Twitter and after the lockup period joined Facebook, or done something else, this seems to be a reprehensible choice.

He was probably a talented CEO, with a larger contribution to the overall project than his co-founders (he alludes to this with his description of there work ethic) and should’ve been deserving of 5 million dollars out of 10 million combined (especially at such an early…
